body:
Yeah, I don't like a separate attribute. That's a failing of the design of NUnit, IMO, one that I'm not anxious to repeat ("floating" attributes which may end up applied in places they don't belong).

Assume the only way to mark something as explicit is via `[Fact(Explicit = true)]` or `[InlineData(1, 2, 3, Explicit = true)]` or the moral equivalent, and then re-frame whether you think `-explicit` is something that should be there or not.

Also, `-filter category==Explicit` seems to imply something I hadn't proposed (which is that explicitness is a category of some kind; we don't have categories, but trait name/value pairs, so what other things would you put under the list of 'category' in filters?)

I'm totally fine without `-filter category==Explicit` ðŸ™‚

And I also like your proposal `[Fact(Explicit = true)]` or `[InlineData(1, 2, 3, Explicit = true)]`, a dedicated attribute doesn't seem necessary to me.  
The only thing I'm not sure about is how to mark a complete class as explicit. Because it seems a little too verbose to me marking all tests within a class with `[Fact(Explicit = true)]`. But it's not a big issue for me, just a little bit inconvenient. What are you thoughts about this?

This seems a very nice proposal for handling known broken tests that are not immediately fixable but need to be able to be run "explicitly" to debug and fix. It will also be useful for special-purpose tests which should only run by request. To be honest these are the two reasons I use "skip" today so probably will convert uses of "skip" to "explicit". For me, if a test should never be run, I remove it or make sure it is not dynamically created via Theory data rather than "skip" it. I see "explicit" as an upgraded form of "skip".

It might be nice (as a secondary thing) to have the option to include "explicit" tests in a normal test run (e.g. to check status of broken tests) but I definitely would prefer explicit tests to be off by default. I guess from above there is a question about whether to make an exception to this when running tests for a class or method (including Theory data) that only has explicit tests. Not sure this is a great idea as means explicit tests could be run by accident (no longer fully opt-in) but don't feel that strongly about this.

Actually the more I think about it, I definitely don't want to accidentally run explicit tests just because e.g. I forgot I removed the only non-explicit test in a class and am testing using the command line. So yes I believe an "explicit" option or something like this should be required to run explicit tests at class/method level even when there are no non-explicit tests. IDEs could then implement intelligent "Run Tests" behaviour (i.e. include "explicit" option) for classes/methods only containing explicit tests because they can use icons to show all tests are explicit etc.

issue.title: Add runner feature to allow forcing to run skipped tests

labels.name: Feature
labels.description: A request for a new feature

repository.name: xunit
repository.description: xUnit.net is a free, open source, community-focused unit testing tool for .NET.

body: Could you please elaborate more on this, e. g. with the help of a code sample? I don't quite get it, sry

Hi @mu88 , no problem, let's take your class `RegularTests` above and let's imagine I run the tests in this class via a script.

If someone comments out the method `RegularTest` (perhaps wrongly) I don't want my script to suddenly start running the explicit test `ExplicitTest` when I have not asked to run explicit tests. This sort of behaviour is fine in an IDE where you probably have visual information about explicit tests (icons) and can then choose to run or not but at the command line I don't want explicit tests to be on or off unpredictably based on code I cannot see (perhaps edited by someone else).

That was the point I was trying to make.
Another way to explain is to say I'd rather not have explicit tests in a class/method run or not depending on *what else* is in the class/method (which may change as code evolves) when using scripts.

> Now when running -class RegularTests (either from the GUI or CLI), I'd expect nothing to happen: ExplicitTest is explicit, so it shouldn't be executed. And since there are no non-explicit tests, that call will not run any tests.

Okay, but you also gave an example above where `[Explicit]` was defined on the class instead of the method and in that case you wanted the explicit test to run. To me the behaviour should be the same regardless of whether `[Explicit]` is applied at class or method level (if indeed such flexibility is supported).

> Only when executing -method RegularTests.ExplicitTest, a test gets executed.

I'm afraid I don't like this. If a Theory method has one non-explicit case which is removed do the explicit cases suddenly start to run without an "explicit" option? I'd rather an "explicit" option was required to run explicit tests in all cases. Like I've said though, I'm expecting this shouldn't restrict IDEs from silently adding an "explicit" option when only explicit tests are requested (so the "explicit" option is invisible to the user).

>The only thing I'm not sure about is how to mark a complete class as explicit.

There's no way to do this without introducing another attribute. I'm tempted to just say this isn't directly supported (you can only mark individual tests or test data as explicit).

>If a Theory method has one non-explicit case which is removed do the explicit cases suddenly start to run without an "explicit" option? I'd rather an "explicit" option was required to run explicit tests in all cases. Like I've said though, I'm expecting this shouldn't restrict IDEs from silently adding an "explicit" option when only explicit tests are requested (so the "explicit" option is invisible to the user).

Yeah, we should separate the GUI from the CLI from a usability standpoint.

In the GUI, you will see which tests were not run because of explicit, and you can select it/them to run them explicitly. I believe this is how other frameworks work today, so this should be fine.

In the CLI, the way I see it there are two potentially competing/complementary options (`-method` and `-explicit`). I believe that, for sure, `-explicit` is a necessary option, because ease of use would suggest you'd want options like `-explicit off` (default), `-explicit on`, and `-explicit only`. So then the remaining question is should `-method` run an explicit method in the absence of the `-explicit` option? (And how about explicit data rows in a test method?)

I'm currently leaning towards "from the CLI, the only way to run explicit tests is with `-explicit on` or `-explicit only`" regardless of usage of `-method`. This could be supplemented by logic which says if you've asked to run a filtered list of tests, and it ended up running nothing because everything you selected was explicit, it could say "Did you mean to add `-explicit on`?"
@bradwilson , makes a lot of sense to me, very much looking forward to xUnit v3!
Are there any considerations/discussions/clarifications missing? It seems to me that it has a relatively mature status
Oh, I am so looking forward to this. One of the very few things I have been missing from NUnit, is the ability to run an ignored test explicitly.

issue.title: v3 Roadmap

repository.name: xunit
repository.description: xUnit.net is a free, open source, community-focused unit testing tool for .NET.

issue.body:
A quick note about this list... It represents a moment in time for planning for a final list of v3 features. Until items are checked off, there is no guarantee that the feature will make it into v3. We reserve the right to rearrange and modify this list at will as we work through the issues and decide whether we can and will implement them.

body:
How the runners we build will handle explicit tests:

- Console runner (individual and meta): `-explicit <off|on|only>` with default of `off`
- MSBuild runner: `<xunit Explicit="<off|on|only>"` with default of `off`
- TDnet runner: Explicit is off for all run gestures except running an individual test method.
- VSTest runner: Explicit is off for "run all", and on for "run test". _[Implementation details TBD]_
	- In Visual Studio, not run tests will be shown as Not Run in their UI. A user who uses the "run all" gesture will not run explicit tests; a user who selects a subset of tests to run from the Test Explorer UI will run explicit tests that are included in the selected list.
	- In VS Code, using the "Run Test" or "Debug Test" to run an individual test that is explicit will run that test; all other gestures will not run explicit tests.

From an extensibility point of view, the only thing that is marked as "explicit" is a test:

https://github.com/xunit/xunit/blob/8af64f2f810911ed8aefc3f19517ba78620e7827/src/xunit.v3.core/Sdk/v3/TestCases/_ITest.cs#L15-L18

Implementations of this are free to thread this through the system as they see fit. For `[Fact]` and friends, this gets surfaced on the test case:

https://github.com/xunit/xunit/blob/8af64f2f810911ed8aefc3f19517ba78620e7827/src/xunit.v3.core/Sdk/v3/Abstractions/IXunitTestCase.cs#L13-L16

https://github.com/xunit/xunit/blob/8af64f2f810911ed8aefc3f19517ba78620e7827/src/xunit.v3.core/Sdk/v3/TestCases/XunitTest.cs#L43-L44

This opens up extensibility opportunities to express explicit-ness at any layer, since `_ITest` is the lowest layer in the stack. I may later introduce `Explicit` as something you could set on an individual data row, and others could come and introduce class-level `[Explicit]` attributes that filter down into test cases and tests in the same way that `[Fact(Explicit)]` filters down from the test case into the test today.

Thx for your awesome work once again, @bradwilson! I'm happy to see this feature coming in `v3` :) any ideas when this version will be available?

And if you consider it useful, I'd be glad to assist you and the project with some coding work. It was not my intention that you have to do this bunch of work only on your own.

> any ideas when this version will be available?

At this point, not sure. I push alpha builds to MyGet but without VSTest support yet, it's still got limited usability. At the moment this is still just a "when I can find time" project, though that may change soon.

> And if you consider it useful, I'd be glad to assist you and the project with some coding work. It was not my intention that you have to do this bunch of work only on your own.

There are a bunch of issues marked with "help wanted". It may be helpful to consult the roadmap as well: https://github.com/xunit/xunit/issues/2133

FYI b54c11d51ef848e008d577aafa1806e04e116498 adds `Explicit` to `ITheoryDataRow` (which is something that will also be supported for `[InlineData]` in #2545):

https://github.com/xunit/xunit/blob/b54c11d51ef848e008d577aafa1806e04e116498/src/xunit.v3.core/ITheoryDataRow.cs#L10-L14

As you can see, this is a nullable-boolean with fallback, so this can override explicitness in both directions (on or off).
